conclusion: To determine the change in average kinetic energy from state D to A, analyze the thermodynamic processes.
The Stirling cycle consists of two isothermal and two isochoric processes.
Isothermal processes occur at constant temperature; isochoric processes occur at constant volume.
In A→B (isothermal expansion), the average kinetic energy remains the same.
In B→C (isochoric cooling), the average kinetic energy decreases.
In C→D (isothermal compression), the average kinetic energy remains the same.
In D→A (isochoric heating), the average kinetic energy increases.
During D to A, since volume is constant and temperature increases, average kinetic energy increases.
The average kinetic energy of gas molecules increases when transitioning from state D to state A.
